data.title: Biography, Movies & Net Worth
data.meta_description: Actor-director Maria Schrader is an exceptional figure in German cinema: An actor-turned-director who has managed to make the leap from German-language movies to directing major American movies, such as She Said (2022).
data.text:
Actor-director Maria Schrader is an exceptional figure in German cinema: An actor-turned-director who has managed to make the leap from German-language movies to directing major American movies, such as She Said (2022), the topical drama about the New York Times investigation of sexual assault accusations against Harvey Weinstein starring Zoe Kazan and Carey Mulligan, with Patricia Clarkson, Andre Braugher, Jennifer Ehle, Samantha Morton, and Ashley Judd (as herself).

Schrader made her big-screen debut in Goldjunge (1988) and followed with her first film under writer-director-actor Dani Levy’s direction, RobbyKallePaul (1989), followed by her next collaboration with Levy (and Schrader’s first screenplay credit and starring role), I Was on Mars (1991).

Schrader played support in writer-director Guy Jacques’ French drama, Call Me Victor (1993), starring Jeanne Moreau, Micheline Presle, Dominique Pinon, and Julien Guiomar, followed by Schrader starring in writer-director Doris Dörrie’s comedy-drama, Nobody Loves Me (1994), with Pierre Sanoussi-Bliss and Elisabeth Trissenaar. In the same year, Maria Schrader co-starred with Anna Thalbach in the Peter Welz-directed crime comedy, Burning Life (1994), with Max Tidof, Dani Levy, and Peter Kern.

Schrader co-starred with Richy Müller, Peter Lohmeyer, and Dani Levy in One of My Oldest Friends (1995), an adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s novel, Babylon Revisited, directed by Rainer Kaufmann, and she starred again under Levy’s direction in Silent Night (1995), with Jürgen Vogel, and Mark Schlichter. In another 1995 project, Schrader co-starred with Levy in Half World, written and directed by Florian Flicker, and premiered at the Torino Film Festival.

Schrader starred in director Robert Dornhelm’s rom-com, The Unfish (also known as The Whale) (1997), with Andreas Lust, premiering in the competition of the Karlovy Vary Film Festival, followed by Schrader’s second co-written and co-starring film (in both English and German) with director-star Levy, The Giraffe (1998), premiering at the Toronto Film Festival. It also marked Schrader’s first credit as director, shared with Levy.

Maria Schrader reunited with filmmaker Doris Dörrie in a supporting role for the comedy-drama, Am I Beautiful? (1998), with Marie Zielcke, Franke Potente, and Suzanne von Borsody, and also played support in writer-director Tomi Streiff’s rom-com, The Wedding Cow (1999), with Isabella Parkinson, Oliver Reinhard, and Dani Levy.

Maria Schrader’s breakthrough performance came with her role as “Jaguar” in writer-director Max Färberböck’s Aimee & Jaguar (1999), with co-stars Schrader and Juliane Köhler sharing the Best Actress Silver Bear prize at the Berlin Film Festival, with Detlev Buck, Inge Keller, and Levy. Croatian writer-director Rajko Grlic directed Schrader as a star in the Croatian-produced, English-language film, Josephine (2000), co-starring Giancarlo Esposito, which Schrader then followed with a co-starring role in writer-director Franziska Buch’s family movie, Emil and the Detectives (2001), with Jürgen Vogel and Kai Wiesinger.

Released in the U.S. and other territories as Advertising Rules! (2001), writer-director Lars Kraume’s comedy had Schrader in a supporting role with Alexander Scheer, Götz George, and Chulpan Khamatova. Schrader made another movie with writer-director Levy, the drama I’m the Father (2002), co-starring Sebastian Blomberg. Schrader followed with the starring role in the movie that marked leading German filmmaker Margarethe von Trotta’s return to features, Rosenstrasse (2003), with Katja Riemann and Martin Wuttke, and premiering at the Venice Film Festival, where it won the UNICEF Award.

After appearing in British filmmaker Peter Greenaway’s historical saga, The Tulse Luper Suitcases Part II: Vaux to the Sea (2004), with JJ Feild, Roger Rees, Ana Torrent, Raymond J. Barry, Ornella Muti, Franka Potente, Isabella Rossellini, and Gaspard Ulliel, Schrader co-starred in writer-producer-director Hans W. Geissendörfer’s Snowland (2005), with Peter Przygodda and Julia Jentsch, and premiering at the Sundance Film Festival. Schrader once again performed under Greenaway’s direction in the Tulse Luper sequel, A Life in Suitcases: A History of Tulse Luper (2005), with Barry, Stephen Billington, Roberto Citran, Michael Culkin, Caroline Dhavernas, Feild, Anna Galiena, Debbie Harry, Muti, Potente, Rees, and Rossellini.

Maria Schrader took on the recurring role of Mutter Kai in writer-director Christian Ditter’s hit feature series based on Max von der Grun’s novel, starting with The Crocodiles (2009), and continuing with the sequels, The Crocodiles Strike Back (2010) and The Crocodiles: All for One (2011). Schrader joined the ensemble of Robert Więckiewicz, Benno Fürmann, Herbert Knaup, and Agnieszka Grochowska in the Agnieszka Holland-directed Holocaust drama, In Darkness (2011), nominated for the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar.

Writer-director Anne Wild’s drama, Sisters (2013), was Schrader’s next starring role, opposite Jesper Christensen, Ursula Werner, and Anna Blomeier, followed by another starring role for Schrader in writer-director Jan Schomburg’s drama, Lose My Self (2014), with Johannes Krisch, Ronald Zehrfeld, Sandra Hüller, and premiering in the Tiger competition at the Rotterdam Film Festival.

Maria Schrader’s first film as solo writer-director was the Austrian-produced biopic (with co-writer Jan Schomburg), Stefan Zweig: Farewell to Europe (2016), starring Josef Hader, Barbara Sukowa, Valerie Pachner, Gabriela Barros, and Tomas Lemarquis, and Austria’s official Oscar submission and winning the People’s Choice Award at the European Film Awards.
